title: Meet Up III: Wrangle dataframes
text:
üìç Hertie School. Seminar Room 2.61
üóì 14:00 - 16:00 hrs, November 24, 2022

Objective: We will go over the fundamentals of data wrangling in R. We will continue exploring methods for cleaning, transforming, and manipulating data using the dplyr package. We‚Äôll discuss data operations like filtering, sorting, joining, and summing up. Participants will leave the session with a firm grasp on the fundamentals of data manipulation in R, which will serve as a solid foundation for further exploration and experimentation with this potent language.

title: Hertie School Kino Club
text:
Description: The Kino Club brings you to Berlin film culture. From blockbusters to arthouse and from Asia to Europe, Kino Club will host and visit diverse screenings and festivals throughout the city. The Club wants to show how film is approached differently throughout the world, how it shapes cultures, and what makes it so unique. Filmmakers and Professors in film will be invited for talks and Q&As. Students get the opportunity to share their own ideas and favourite topics in film by organizing their own screenings. Events will be held both at Hertie and externally.
Contact persons:

title: Ridhima Singh
text: I‚Äôm Ridhima, and I‚Äôm currently pursuing my Master‚Äôs in Public Policy from Hertie and the London School of Economics. I discovered my love for data analysis during my time as a consultant for the Government of India, and am now excited to dive deeper into the world of policy, data and strategic decision making.

title: Carmen Garro
text: I am Carmen, from Costa Rica. I did my undergrad in Statistics. I have worked in the internacional organization and public sectors. My intereses are in evidence made decision making, specially in public policy formulation.

title: Huy Dang
text: Huy Dang is the Manager of the Data Science Lab and the Coordinator for the Master of Data Science for Public Policy at the Hertie School. Before joining Hertie, he was a government official at the Ministry of Finance of Vietnam and a strategic investment specialist in IFC-compliant development projects. His interest is primarily in the field of machine learning, AI-generated art, and computer vision.

title: Jorge Roa
text:
Hello! I‚Äôm Jorge! I have a B.A. in Public Policy and a passion for using data to inform decision-making. My interests include:

üéØ Data Science for Public Policy: I‚Äôm in my second year of the Master‚Äôs degree in Data Science for Public Policy at Hertie School in Berlin, Germany. I believe that data science can be a powerful tool for addressing complex public policy challenges, and I‚Äôm excited to continue exploring this field. My interest is use data science as a tool to inform decision-making and maximize the impact of a policy in real and complex environments. contexts
üè¢ Work: I‚Äôm involve in multiple research projects within the Project for Analysis and Decision in Uncertain Contexts. For example, I‚Äôve been estimating the force of infection of the bacteria Helicobacter Pylori (which causes gastric cancer) on the US population using catalytic models. Also, I‚Äôve started to implement Discrete Event Simulation in the natural history of colorrectal cancer as well as other activities related to cancer research for different CISNET groups.
üèõ Teaching and Education: I‚Äôm passionate about teaching. I‚Äôve worked as a teaching assistant for courses on quantitative methods and public policy evaluation. I‚Äôm also the founder of the Hertie Coding Club, a space where students can learn programming skills for data analysis, wrangling and public policy.
üé´ Memberships: I‚Äôm part of the Gastric Cancer Group from the Cancer Intervention and Surveillance Modeling Network (CISNET); Trainee member of the Society for Medical Decision Making (SMDM) and a member of Stanford‚Äôs Data Science x Decision Science DS^2 group.

title: Simon Munzert
text:
About Me 

I‚Äôm Professor of Data Science and Public Policy at the Hertie School in Berlin and Director of the Data Science Lab. My research focuses on public opinion, attitude formation in the digital age, and the use of online data in social research. I use experimental methods, online data, and innovative measurement strategies to study how people act and think, politically.


Publications 

See here for an overview of my current research and publications.

 Andrew Guess et al.¬†The consequences of online partisan media. PNAS.
 Sascha G√∂bel and Simon Munzert. The Comparative Legislators Database. British Journal of Political Science.
 Simon Munzert et al.¬†Tracking and Promoting the Usage of a COVID-19 Contact Tracing App. Nature Human Behaviour.
 Simon Munzert et al.¬†Do Online Voter Guides Empower Citizens? Evidence from a Field Experiment with Digital Trace Data. Public Opinion Quarterly.



Teaching 

I regularly teach graduate students about causal inference, online data collection, and computational social science in general. You can find syllabi here.

Automated Data Collection with R

title: Hertie Coding Club Statutes
text:
Section 1: Eligibility
Membership in the Hertie Coding Club is open to all members of the Hertie community, including students, faculty, staff, and alumni, regardless of their background or experience in coding.

title: Hertie Coding Club Statutes
text:
Section 2: Responsibilities
Members are expected to actively participate in club activities, contribute to a positive learning environment, and maintain a respectful attitude towards fellow members.

title: Hertie Coding Club Statutes
text:
Section 1: Composition
The Executive Committee shall consist of the following positions: President, Vice President, Treasurer, and Communications Officer.

title: Hertie Coding Club Statutes
text:
Section 2: Duties

President: Oversee club operations, lead meetings, and represent the club within the Hertie community and beyond.
Vice President: Assist the President and assume their duties in their absence, coordinate club activities, and manage subcommittees.
Treasurer: Manage club finances, including budgeting, fundraising, and allocation of resources.
Communications Officer: Oversee club communications, promote events and activities, and maintain the club‚Äôs online presence.

title: Hertie Coding Club Statutes
text:
Section 3: Elections
Elections shall be held annually during the last meeting of the academic year. All club members are eligible to run for a position. The new memebers will be choose by the President at that time.

title: Hertie Coding Club Statutes
text:
Section 1: Frequency
Regular club meetings shall be held at least once per month during the academic year. Additional meetings, workshops, or events may be scheduled as needed.

title: Hertie Coding Club Statutes
text:
Section 2: Quorum
A quorum shall consist of at least 50% of the club‚Äôs active membership. Decisions shall be made by a majority vote of members present at a meeting with a quorum.

title: Hertie Coding Club Statutes
text:
Section 1: Budget
The Treasurer shall prepare an annual budget for the club, detailing anticipated revenues and expenses for the academic year. The budget shall be approved by the Executive Committee and presented to the club membership for review.

title: Hertie Coding Club Statutes
text:
Section 2: Fundraising
The club may engage in fundraising activities to support its operations and initiatives. All fundraising activities shall be conducted in accordance with applicable laws, regulations, and Hertie community guidelines.

title: Hertie Coding Club Statutes
text:
Section 3: Financial Reporting
The Treasurer shall provide regular financial reports to the Executive Committee and club membership, detailing the club‚Äôs financial status and transactions.

title: Gabriel Zech
text: I have been working as a project manager in the field of data science for public policy research since 2019. Having helped set up a Data Science Lab at the Bertelsmann Stiftung, I am particularly interested in how to systematically develop an organisation‚Äôs infrastructure, governance and culture in the field of data science. Going forward I want to further focus on working at the intersection between management and technical teams.

title: David Garibay
text: I am David, a Data Analyst and a Senior Associate at PADeCI (Spanish acronym for Project of Decision Analysis under Uncertain Contexts). Here, I develop decision-analytic models in health policy, particularly in colorectal and bladder cancer. I am also part of the Bladder cancer modeling group of the Cancer Intervention and Surveillance Modeling Network (CISNET), a member of the Society for Medical Decision Making (SMDM), and a member of Stanford‚Äôs Data Science x Decision Science (DS^2) group. I have a bachelor‚Äôs degree in economics and a master‚Äôs in methods for public policy analysis. I support evidence-based policymaking, and I consider that data science is a required foundation to generate rigorous and reproducible research.

title: Rodrigo Dornelles
text:
Initially a lawyer with experience in criminal law, strategic litigation, and public law, I‚Äôve now developed a strong passion for harnessing data analysis and data science to serve the public good. My diverse roles have included Research Assistant at the Hertie School Data Science Lab, Visiting Scholar at UC Berkeley, Attorney at Conectas Human Rights, and Chief Advisor at the Penitentiary Administration in Maranh√£o, Brazil.
My multidisciplinary background in law, public policy, and public management drives me to address complex social challenges such as public security, access to justice, and enhancing government effectiveness. I‚Äôm always eager to collaborate with like-minded professionals to create innovative solutions that leave a lasting, positive impact on communities worldwide, with a special focus on Latin America.

title: Lukas Lehmann

title: Valeria Gracia
text: I am a doctoral student in Health Policy at Stanford University and a Fulbright-Garc√≠a Robles scholar. title: Ann Wells
text:
Hi! I‚Äôm Ann and the founder of SHARE. I have a Ph.D.¬†in Genome Science and Technology and a Master‚Äôs in Statistics from the University of Tennessee-Knoxville. Currently, I am a postdoctoral associate at the Jackson Laboratory working in Dr.¬†Gregory Carter‚Äôs laboratory. I am wet and dry systems biologist that investigates systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE, lupus) using multiple -omics, multiple tissues, and potential therapeutics to tease out the molecular underpinnings that contribute to SLE progression.
As a proponent of open science I develop novel ways of disseminating research that are: - transparent - reproducible - bridge the gap between non-computational and computational biologists - make every aspect of research FAIR - create a homepage for each research project to find code, data, results, etc.
Outside of research I want to empower non-computational biologists to obtain the computational skills necessary to perform preliminary analyses on their own data. I do this through teaching as a software carpentry instructor.
When I‚Äôm not thinking about science I am often riding my bike on the beautiful park loop in Acadia National Park, going for hikes, working out, or generally enjoying the amazing island I live on.

title: Setting up your environment in Python
text:
üìç Hertie School. Seminar Room 2.34
üóì 13:00 hrs, February 24, 2023

Objective: The main learning outcome is for you to know how to set up reproducible and shareable environments for Python projects, understand how to effectively switch between environments when using an IDE and how to work more efficiently with IDEs, including how to use jupyter code cells within a .py script (a personal favourite of mine). The workshop will focus on Pipenv (the environment and packaging tool officially recommended by the Python developer community) and VSCode (a very customizable and efficient IDE). Nevertheless, the ideas and workflows covered here also apply for other tools (like Anaconda or venv, Sypder or Pycharm).
